The GOLDEN NOIR look is all about the perfect balance between radiant gold eyes and a velvety nude lip.

Chic Mono Eyeshadow in Shimmer Gold 17 creates a creamy, buildable gold shimmer, while Fabulous Eyeliner defines with a smooth, mistake-free wing. Fabulous Eyes Mascara adds volume, curl, and lift, perfectly complementing the soft, blurring effect of Fabulous Kiss Blur Matte Lipstick in Nude Smile 140.

The result? A luminous, bold eye paired with a plush, neutral lip—creating a look that’s the epitome of #HerreraBeauty.

Shop the look online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

GOLDEN NOIR by #HerreraBeauty

Transform your look with the perfect balance of gold shimmer, bold liner, and a velvety nude lip:

Step 1. Apply Chic Mono Eyeshadow in Shimmer Gold 17 all over your eyelids for a creamy, buildable gold shimmer that melts into the skin.
Step 2. Create a flawless wing with Fabulous Eyeliner, its waterproof, flexible formula allowing for easy, mistake-free lines.
Step 3. Add lashings of Fabulous Eye Smudgeproof Mascara for incredible volume, curl, and lift that lasts all day.
Step 4. Finish with Fabulous Kiss Blur Matte Lipstick in Nude Smile 140, leaving lips plump and velvety soft for up to 12 hours.

Radiant, powerful, and impossible to ignore.

Shop the look online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

GOLDEN NOIR by #HerreraBeaty.

The perfect mix of rich shimmer and bold definition. Shimmering gold eyes, striking winged liner, voluminous lashes, and a plump, velvety nude lip. 

Shop the look and discover the entire collection online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

The QUARTZ GLOW look is all about the perfect balance between bold eyes and a strong lip. 

Chic Mono Eyeshadow in Metallic Quartz 07 creates a luminous, translucent base, while Fabulous Eyeliner adds striking definition. Fabulous Eyes Waterproof Mascara builds dramatic volume and length, complementing the intensity of Fabulous Kiss Matte Lipstick in our signature red, Carolina 310. 

The result? A soft, bitten red lip that perfectly contrasts the boldness of the eyes, creating a look that’s essentially #HerreraBeauty.

Shop the look online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

QUARTZ GLOW by #HerreraBeauty

A look that captures light and depth: translucent shimmer, precise eyeliner, bold lashes, and a perfectly soft matte red lip.

Shop the look and discover the entire collection online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

QUARTZ GLOW by #HerreraBeauty

Elevate your look with the perfect mix of shimmer, precision, and a signature red lip:

Step 1. Sweep Chic Mono Eyeshadow in Metallic Quartz 07 over your lids for a translucent, wet-look glow that works beautifully on every skin tone.
Step 2. Create striking designs with Fabulous Eyeliner, its smooth-glide formula and precision tip making bold lines effortless.
Step 3. Add drama with Fabulous Eye Mascara in Waterproof, giving you extra-black, defined lashes with extra length for up to 24 hours.
Step 4. Complete the look with a freshly bitten effect using Fabulous Kiss Matte Lipstick in Carolina 310—a soft matte red that stays vibrant and never compromises on comfort.

Refined, radiant, and unmistakably Herrera.

Shop the look online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

#HerreraInCDMX

The Carolina Herrera runway show in CDMX took place at the iconic Museo Anahuacalli (@anahuacalli) in Coyoacán, a project conceptualized by Diego Rivera in collaboration with his daughter Ruth Rivera and architect Juan O’Gorman. The museum houses Mexico’s largest private pre-Hispanic collection and is designed as a pyramid, set within a fourhectare native garden, with an extension building conceived by architect Mauricio Rocha in 2021.

Museo Anahuacalli Director Teresa Moya and Curator Karla Niño de Rivera (@karlaninno) shared insights into this extraordinary project.

Film by @aranmartinezsolana.

-

El desfile de Carolina Herrera en CDMX tuvo lugar en el icónico Museo Anahuacalli (@anahuacalli) en Coyoacán, un proyecto conceptualizado por Diego Rivera en colaboración con Juan O’Gorman y su hija Ruth Rivera. El museo alberga la colección privada prehispánica más grande de México y está diseñado como una pirámide, ubicada dentro de un jardín nativo de cuatro hectáreas, con un edificio anexo concebido por el arquitecto Mauricio Rocha en 2021.

La directora del Museo Anahuacalli, Teresa Moya, y la curadora del mismo, Karla Niño de Rivera (@karlaninno), comparten detalles sobre este extraordinario proyecto.

En el corazón de México late la artesanía. Con motivo del desfile Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, que se presentó en el Museo Anahuacalli el 14 de noviembre, el director creativo @wesgordon colaboró con cuatro artesanas que conservan y proyectan al futuro la sabiduría de sus comunidades.
En San Isidro Buen Suceso (Tlaxcala), Virginia Verónica Arce Arce @vicky.arce.946179 ha refinado los bordados tradicionales con motivos que rinden homenaje a la cultura nahua. Las joyas que Araceli Nibra Matadamas @aracelinibra pinta y decora a mano a partir de jícaras son fruto de la cultura artesanal de Oaxaca. 

–

At the heart of Mexico lies its vibrant artisanal tradition. For the Resort 25 collection, presented at the Museo Anahuacalli on November 14, creative director Wes Gordon ( @wesgordon ) collaborated with four women artisans who honor and reimagine the wisdom of their communities.
In San Isidro Buen Suceso, Tlaxcala, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce ( @vicky.arce.946179 ) refines traditional embroidery with motifs cele

En el corazón de México late la artesanía. Con motivo del desfile Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, que se presentó en el Museo Anahuacalli el 14 de noviembre, el director creativo @wesgordon colaboró con cuatro artesanas que conservan y proyectan al futuro la sabiduría de sus comunidades.
Los bordados de Maestra María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan @mariadelosangeleslicona (El Nanthe, Tenango de Doria, Hildalgo) son una oda a la belleza natural de la región y se plasman en diez prendas con contrastes de color. En Tlaxcala, Jacqueline España Capilla @jacqueline.espana.joyeria ha sabido reinterpretar la talavera tradicional, una cerámica esmaltada en blanco y azul cuyo origen se remonta a las culturas prehispánicas, para crear joyas y detalles ornamentales para varios modelos de la colección.

–

At the heart of Mexico lies its vibrant artisanal tradition. For the Resort 25 collection, presented at the Museo Anahuacalli on November 14, creative director Wes Gordon ( @wesgordon ) collaborated with four women artis

En San Isidro Buen Suceso (Tlaxcala), en las faldas de La Malinche, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce @vicky.arce.946179 crea bordados inspirados en la belleza natural de su entorno. Su padre le enseñó a bordar cuando tenía 15 años y desde entonces se esfuerza por mantener viva una artesanía que también forma parte de la identidad de su comunidad. Con la ayuda de una vieja máquina de coser, ha elevado su oficio gracias a su exigencia y sensibilidad. En la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, las franjas bordadas de Virginia Verónica Arce Arce protagonizan tres vestidos que reflejan también el amor por la belleza y la naturaleza de esta comunidad de Tlaxcala. 

–

In San Isidro Buen Suceso, Tlaxcala, at the foothills of La Malinche, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce ( @vicky.arce.946179 ) creates embroidery inspired by the natural beauty around her. Her father taught her to embroider at age 15, and she has since dedicated herself to preserving a craft that is integral to her community’s identity. With the help of an o

En San Pablo del Monte, Tlaxcala, se trabaja la talavera, una delicada cerámica esmaltada en blanco lechoso y azul. A Jacqueline España Capilla @jacqueline.espana.joyeria le fascinaba desde la infancia. Cuando acabó sus estudios de ingeniería química, decidió experimentar con ella y explorar sus límites. “Aquí, la talavera es una especie de reliquia que tienes guardada, que se utiliza como adorno o se saca en las ocasiones especiales, y yo quería llevarla conmigo todo el tiempo, usarla día a día”, explica esta artesana implicada con el desarrollo de su comunidad. En su colaboración para la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, sus joyas adornan vestidos y complementos. “Como artesana productora de talavera tengo el compromiso de cuidar el patrimonio que me fue legado, y velar por su salvaguarda, cuidando su esencia e impulsando la innovación”.

–

Talavera, a delicate white and blue glazed ceramic, has long been cherished in San Pablo del Monte, Tlaxcala. Jacqueline España Capilla ( @jacqueline.espana.joye

Araceli Nibra Matadamas @aracelinibra vive y trabaja en Oaxaca, uno de los epicentros de la artesanía en México. Por eso colabora con toda una red de artesanos de confianza para reivindicar ciertos oficios desde una óptica contemporánea. Trabaja con latoneros, bordadoras o pintores, y ella misma decora jícaras con pintura, bordado, macramé y otros materiales. En el desfile de la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, Araceli Nibra colabora con una serie de piezas de joyería que reinterpretan sus célebres jícaras y emplean distintos materiales naturales.

–

Araceli Nibra Matadamas ( @aracelinibra ) lives and works in Oaxaca, one of Mexico’s craft epicenters. She collaborates with a trusted network of artisans to celebrate traditional crafts through a contemporary lens. Working with metalsmiths, embroiderers, painters, and more, she also hand-decorates jícaras using paint, embroidery, macramé, and other materials. For Carolina Herrera’s Resort 25 collection, Araceli Nibra contributed a series of jewelry piec

Maestra María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan @mariadelosangeleslicona aprendió a bordar de niña. En aquella época no había escuelas para las comunidades indígenas de El Nanthe, en Tenango de Doria (Hidalgo). “Pero con el apoyo de la costura he sacado adelante a mis ocho hijos”, explica. “La manta es mi cuaderno y la aguja es mi lapicero”. Para la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, María de los Ángeles Licona ha creado los bordados de diez prendas. 

–

María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan ( @mariadelosangeleslicona ) learned embroidery as a child. At the time, there were no schools for the Indigenous communities of El Nanthe in Tenango de Doria, Hidalgo. “But thanks to sewing, I’ve been able to support my eight children,” she explains. “The fabric is my notebook, and the needle is my pen.” For Carolina Herrera’s Resort 25 collection, María de los Ángeles Licona created the embroidery for ten garments.

Come behind the scenes of our Resort 25 collection, as the brand’s decades-long bond with Mexico comes to life in a collection celebrating craftsmanship, culture, and inspiration. Drawing from the luminous sunsets of Mexico City, Wes Gordon collaborated with four artisans to create one-of-a-kind pieces that honor the best of Mexican artistry. Featuring works by Maestra María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce, Jacqueline España Capilla and Araceli Nibra Matadamas; this collection pays tribute to the cultures that continue to shape the brand.

Our first-ever see-now-buy-now collection will be available at carolinaherrera.com and select stores.

OPTIMISM AT PLAY: The Carolina Herrera Spring 25 collection begins in a study of black and white, with a considered focus on one exclamation point accentuating each look.

The collection blooms into color, in a tightly edited palette of four bold hues. Creative Director, Wes Gordon seeks perfection in each piece through the most precise choice of color, cut and silhouette, with an exacting dedication to graphic glamour. Adorned with yellow roses in their hair, models circle Isamu Noguchi’s circular Sunken Garden installation (1964), an ode to perfection in simplicity resonant in this collection, the polka dots in playful dialogue with the concentric circles of the sculpture.

Yesterday evening, our founder Carolina Herrera was honored with the 2024 Hispanic Heritage Award for Fashion at the 37th Annual Hispanic Heritage Awards (HHAs) at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts’ Opera House in Washington, D.C. The award was presented to her by her dear friend, Musican and Producer Emilio Estefan.

The HHAs, supported by 40 national Hispanic-serving institutions, were established by The White House in 1988 to commemorate the creation of Hispanic Heritage Month in America, which is why they are often known as “America’s Hispanic Heritage Month Celebration.”

“The Hispanic Heritage Foundation is thrilled to honor the transcendent Carolina Herrera, a true global icon who has represented our community with such tremendous vision, determination and grace throughout her historic career,” said Antonio Tijerino, HHF President and CEO.

“It is an honor to receive the prestigious Hispanic Heritage Award which recognizes the tremendous contributions and legacy of Latinos in the United States and the world,” says Carolina. “I am proud to have the chance to celebrate our rich heritage and achievements with my fellow honorees. Thank you to the Hispanic Heritage Foundation for this great honor.”

Catalan artist @rosa_tharrats has transformed leftover Carolina Herrera textiles into ingenious sculptural pieces as part of a new exhibition in Barcelona. Her work stitches together textiles, upholstery, and clothing to create intricate installations that explore our relationship with organic and inorganic materials.

Carolina Herrera believes in empowering women in the arts — go see Tharrats’s new show in person at @bombonprojects, open until May 4. 

Photography by @albayruela

Textile artist @rosa_tharrats shows us what happens when incredible women and fashion come together for the sake of art: for her new show at @bombonprojects in Barcelona, Tharrats used leftover Carolina Herrera textiles in her amazing sculptural pieces, including a show stopping blue and green tapestry covering the walls of the gallery that was built entirely with recycled fabrics.

“With the Carolina Herrera fabrics I used, I love the way they hang, the way they drape, and their colors,” she says.

Refugia is open to the public at @bombonprojects in Barcelona until May 4.

Photography by @albayruela

In our ongoing mission to celebrate women in the arts, Carolina Herrera has joined forces with Catalan artist @rosa_tharrats for a new gallery show in Barcelona. 

Tharrats is a visual artist who utilizes fabric for incredibly intricate sculptural pieces, exploring the relationship between organic and inorganic materials. 

For her Refugia exhibition — open to the public at @bombonprojects in Barcelona until May 4 — Carolina Herrera has donated leftover textiles from CHNY collections for her to use, including a show stopping blue and green tapestry covering the walls of the gallery. 

“My goal is to create sensorial atmospheres with layers of meaning,” she says.

Dive into the allure of Amazonian Rose with an intimate gathering in Mexico City, where art, design, music, and friends got together to celebrate the new fragrance.

Inspired by the lush gardens of the Herrera family home in Venezuela, its captivating blend of cardamom, Damask rose, incense, and myrrh captures the essence of Latin America's vibrant heritage.

#HerreraConfidential

Carolina Herrera celebrated the release of Amazonian Rose, the new fragrance from the Herrera Confidential collection, at an intimate event in the heart of Coyoacán, Mexico City. 

The scent is a tribute to Latin America, with hints of cardamom, Damask rose, incense, and myrrh that evoke the lush gardens of the Herrera family home in Venezuela.

#HerreraConfidential

Beauty Creative Director Carolina A. Herrera and Creative Director @wesgordon sit together to talk about the newest Herrera Confidential fragrance, Amazonian Rose.

“I love that idea that you found this magical odorless flower,” says Creative Director @wesgordon, “and you created for it its scent.” 

#HerreraCondifential

Introducing Amazonian Rose, the newest edition to Herrera Confidential. Inspired by a scentless flower, Amazonian Rose harks back to the early days of Mrs. Herrera's creative and artistic life, especially to Hacienda La Vega, her home in the heart of Caracas where a unique plant called 'La Rosa de Venezuela' thrived in the lush gardens.

"It's a flower that I grew up seeing. Yet, this flower has no scent," says Beauty Creative Director Carolina A. Herrera. "So, we decided to give it one."

To evoke the memories and sensations, Amazonian Rose combines cardamom from Guatemala, Damask rose, incense, and myrrh, all encased in a strikingly Herrera red glass bottle.

#HerreraConfidential

The New York artist @maripolarama is famous for her Polaroid portraits of notable names. Now, she’s turned her lens on the models who walked the fabulous FW24 show, including @palomija, @carolinetrentini, @dibaamaty, and @irinashayk.

Backstage at the FW24 show, we caught up with New York artist @maripolarama, who, just like Carolina Herrera, first made a name for herself in the gritty, glamorous New York of the 1970s and '80s. It all came together at Studio 54, the Manhattan nightclub that everyone who was anyone — from Mick Jagger to Paloma Picasso, from Truman Capote to Mrs. Herrera herself — visited. 

Maripol is known for capturing portraits of the icons of that infamous era — like Andy Warhol, Grace Jones, Bianca Jagger, and Mrs. Herrera herself — with her famous Polaroid camera. Now, our Creative Director @wesgordon has asked her to turn her lens on Carolina Herrera’s FW 24 show.

Backstage at the FW 24 show, we caught up with New York artist @maripolarama, who, just like Carolina Herrera, first made a name for herself in the gritty, glamorous New York of the 1970s and ’80s. It all came together at Studio 54, the Manhattan nightclub that everyone who was anyone — from Mick Jagger to Paloma Picasso, from Truman Capote to Mrs. Herrera herself — visited. 

Maripol is known for capturing portraits of the icons of that infamous era — like Andy Warhol, Grace Jones, Bianca Jagger, and Mrs. Herrera herself — with her famous Polaroid camera. Now, our Creative Director @wesgordon has asked her to turn her lens on Carolina Herrera’s FW 24 show. 

Makeup by @chichisaito 
Hair by @paulpodlucky
Video by @hugojozwicki

The most beautiful women I know are powerful, strong and resilient. I designed the Carolina Herrera Fall 2024 collection to reflect this strength.

Silhouettes are streamlined, precise and clean. Ruffles are undulating and architectural in their form. Embellishments are intricately woven, beaded and embroidered. I am obsessed with the pursuit of craft.

New experiments in color blocking and new ways of dividing colors on the body in strong and intriguing combinations represent the next evolution in my language of color.

I am continually reaching for the height of elegance, the height of craft, the height of embellishment and that perfect detail. - @wesgordon

Black diamonds are the rare stone that absorb light instead of reflect it — now, as seen on Emirati equestrian @marwaalhash, you can spritz that spirit of scintillating shine right on your wrist with Iris Empire, inspired by one of the most uncommon gems in the world and part of our luxury Herrera Confidential Collection.  

#HerreraConfidential

Black diamonds, those astoundingly rare and precious gems, can take over a billion years to form under the surface of the earth — now, as part of our exclusive Herrera Confidential Collection, we’ve captured their essence in a new fragrance, Iris Empire, with orris, davana, patchouli and leather, and the extraordinary scent of iris. 

#HerreraConfidential

A black diamond is exceedingly uncommon, but, for our premiere Herrera Confidential Collection we’ve captured its essence in a new fragrance, Iris Empire, as seen on Emirati equestrian @marwaalhash. Now, you can spritz the spirit of rarity and brilliance right on your wrist. 

#HerreraConfidential

Paradise in Palm Beach: Our new Palm Beach boutique is now open on 150 Worth Avenue. The new Carolina Herrera outpost is a 2,200 square foot corner location to house the brand’s luxury women’s ready to wear collection, as well as accessories including handbags, shoes and jewelry. The store’s design reflects Creative Director Wes Gordon’s vision expressed first at the renovation of the flagship on Madison Avenue in New York.

As part of the Carolina Herrera Social Justice Scholars Program, a scholarship initiative in partnership with New York’s Fashion Institute of Technology, select female students will be supported throughout the four years of her studies.

“FIT imparts skills and ideas that will be with these young students for the rest of their lives,” says Beauty Creative Director Carolina A. Herrera.

The positive impact of education is at the heart of the Carolina Herrera Social Justice Scholars Program, a scholarship initiative in partnership with New York’s Fashion Institute of Technology which will support select female students throughout the four years of her studies. 

“FIT brings dreams of a career in fashion to fruition,” says Herrera Creative Director Wes Gordon. “We believe that education is the key to empowering the next generation of creatives.”

As part of its mission to celebrate women through the arts, Carolina Herrera is proud to announce the sponsorship of the ‘Maestras’ (‘Women Masters’) Exhibition at the iconic Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum in Madrid, opening October 31 through February 4. The exhibit, curated by Rocío de la Villa, features paintings and sculptures by 73 groundbreaking female artists from the 16th to 20th centuries whose talent prevailed despite prejudice, discrimination and inequitable treatment, in an unexpected exploration on womenhood through symbolism, sisterhood, work, motherhood and beyond, as protagonists of their own fates.

Thanks to @museothyssen
Video by @albayruela

[Exhibition in collaboration with CAM.]

As part of its mission to celebrate women through the arts, Carolina Herrera is proud to announce the sponsorship of the ‘Maestras’ (‘Women Masters’) Exhibition at the iconic Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum in Madrid, opening October 31 through February 4. The exhibit, curated by Rocío de la Villa, features paintings and sculptures by 73 groundbreaking female artists from the 16th to 20th centuries whose talent prevailed despite prejudice, discrimination and inequitable treatment, in an unexpected exploration on womenhood through symbolism, sisterhood, work, motherhood and beyond, as protagonists of their own fates.

Artemisia Gentileschi, 'Judit and her Maidservant' (1618-1619)
Henriette Browne, 'A North-African Fellah' (1867)
Mary Cassatt, detail of 'Louise Nursing Her Child' (1898-1899)
Mary Cassatt, 'Breakfast in Bed' (1897)
Käthe Kollwitz, 'Mother with Two Children' (1980)

Thanks to @museothyssen
Pictures by @albayruela

[Exhibition in collaboration with CAM.]

As part of its mission to celebrate women through the arts, Carolina Herrera is proud to announce the sponsorship of the ‘Maestras’ (‘Women Masters’) Exhibition at the iconic Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum in Madrid, opening October 31 through February 4. The exhibit, curated by Rocío de la Villa, features paintings and sculptures by 73 groundbreaking female artists from the 16th to 20th centuries whose talent prevailed despite prejudice, discrimination and inequitable treatment, in an unexpected exploration on womenhood through symbolism, sisterhood, work, motherhood and beyond, as protagonists of their own fates.

Louise Moillon, detail of ‘Still Life with Fruit’ (around 1637)
[Carmen Thyssen collection.] 

Thanks to @museothyssen
Video by @albayruela

[Exhibition in collaboration with CAM.]

Some scents stay with you for life — Mystery Tobacco, from our Herrera Confidential Collection, is inspired by traveling around the world and a hint of exotic pipe smoke Mrs. Herrera remembers from childhood that evoked faraway lands. With patchouli, ginger, vetiver, and tonka bean, it’s a fragrance that evokes wanderlust, daydreaming, and a quiet notion of the unknown. 

#HerreraConfidential

With the strength of stallions and the warmth of home, Stallion Leather is inspired by Mrs. Herrera’s childhood infatuation with equestrian life. From our Herrera Confidential Collection, the scent combines ginger, jasmine (Mrs. Herrera’s favorite flower), citrus, and incense for an intense, nostalgic blend with plenty of horsepower.

#HerreraConfidential

Picture it: Caracas in the 1970s, the soft scent of flowers in the air. Burning Rose, from our Herrera Confidential Collection, is inspired by the floral arrangements that Mrs. Herrera would create during her stays at Hacienda La Vega, her home in Venezuela. With a blend of Damask rose, black pepper, ginger, cinnamon, patchouli, and myrrh, it’s both comforting and exciting at once — the perfect bouquet.

#HerreraConfidential

Model and Muse Maggie Maurer is captured by Elizaveta Porodina in the upcoming book “COLORMANIA: Color and Fashion.” 
 
Of her collaboration with Creative Director and the House of Herrera on this body of work, Elizaveta shares “The unified aspect of the photo shoots is that they were heavily inspired by fashion illustration and heavily centered on the muse. At heart, they were basically studies of color.”
 
Get notified on when COLORMANIA arrives in stores by signing up on www.carolinaherrera.com
#COLORMANIA

Creative Director @WesGordon has collaborated with photographer @ElizavetaPorodina on the book “COLORMANIA: Color and Fashion”, in partnership with publishing house @Rizzolibooks, set to be released on September 5th. 
 
With a foreword by British Vogue’s Editor in Chief and Vogue European Editorial Director @EdwardEnninful, COLORMANIA is a culmination of four years of creative partnership and a celebration of fashion, color, movement and beauty, featuring muses of different disciplines from dance (NYCB’s Wendy Whelan), modelling (Maggie Maurer, cover) to stage and music (Dove Cameron.) 
 
“The entire philosophy at Carolina Herrera is to embrace color, beauty, and alegría de vivir.  Elizaveta photographs in a very distinct painterly style, whereby she swaths color like a painter brushes color on a canvas.” says Wes. 
 
Get notified on when COLORMANIA arrives in stores by signing up on www.carolinaherrera.com

Big dreams are built step by step; for dressmaking, every stitch is essential to turning a fashion fantasy into reality.

Meet the class of exciting young talent enrolled in the brand Carolina Herrera course devoted to fashion and dressmaking at @spectaculu, a non-profit organization based in Rio de Janeiro that provides training and professional guidance to young people in the entertainment industry.

“It’s the place where you can express your feelings and sensibilities,” says Eduarda, 21 years old. “It’s a form of self-knowledge, of self-expression.”

#HERRERAINRIO

Pictures by @gleesonpaulino

Introducing the next generation of fashion talent: meet the students enrolled in the brand-new Carolina Herrera course devoted to fashion and dressmaking at @spectaculu, a non-profit organization based in Rio de Janeiro that provides training and professional guidance to young people in the entertainment industry.

#HERRERAINRIO

Pictures by @gleesonpaulino

Lady Gaga is who first opened the eyes of Pérola, 21 years old, to the possibility of a life in fashion; now, Pérola is one of 15 students in Rio de Janeiro selected to participate in the brand-new Carolina Herrera fashion and dressmaking class at @spectaculu, a non-profit organization that provides training to young people.

“I needed to enter this world,” Pérola says of the fashion industry, “and fully immerse myself.”

#HERRERAINRIO

Video by @bella_newman

Eduarda is one of 15 students enrolled in the brand-new Carolina Herrera fashion and dressmaking class at @spectaculu, a non-profit organization in Rio De Janeiro that provides training to young people.

“Each person has a different way of dressing,” Eduarda says, “and being different is good.”

#HERRERAINRIO

Video by @bella_newman

Meet Lais, one of 15 students based in Rio de Janeiro, selected to participate in the brand-new Carolina Herrera fashion and dressmaking class at @spectaculu, a non-profit organization that provides training to young people.

“They spend their whole lives telling us how we should dress, how we should behave, how we should act,” says Lais. “And fashion is able to break through the nonsense.” 

#HERRERAINRIO

Video by @bella_newman

Carolina Herrera is immensely proud to announce its new partnership with @spectaculu, a non-profit organization based in Rio de Janeiro that provides training and professional guidance to young people.

In September, the school will open a new Carolina Herrera course devoted to fashion and dressmaking, in furthering its mission of empowering communities through arts and creation. 15 young people will have access to a professional training course guiding them as they take their first steps into the fashion world. In addition, their initial class will be a virtual masterclass thought by none other than Wes Gordon — creative director of Carolina Herrera New York — himself.

Bem-vindos à Spectaculu!

#HERRERAINRIO

An ode to color and beautiful Rio de Janeiro, Carolina Herrera Creative Director @wesgordon’s Resort 24 runway makeup look ideated by Beauty Creative Director Carolina A. Herrera features sun-kissed skin and a bold red lip in #HerreraBeauty’s signature lipstick shade Carolina 310 in the Sheer, Satin, Matte and Blur Matte finishes. 

🛍 Shop the collection online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

Pictures by @gleesonpaulino

#HERRERABEAUTY
#HERRERAINRIO

Reflecting Rio de Janeiro’s joyful, light-hearted spirit, #HerreraBeauty Creative Director Carolina A. Herrera chose a timeless red lip in Carolina 310, the House’s signature lipstick shade, for Carolina Herrera Creative Director @wesgordon’s first ever destination runway collection.

Here’s how to recreate the makeup look of the Resort 24 show: 

LIPS: 
The secret to smooth, seamless lip color is starting with properly prepped lips. First, hydrate your lips using the Good Girl Mini Tint balm in Carolina (nº 310). Then, choose your favorite lipstick finish – Sheer, Satin, Matte or Blur Matte, and apply the Fabulous Kiss Lipstick in the same red shade (nº 310). 

EYES: 
On the eyes, a subtle placement of the Chic Mono Eyeshadow Matte in Chocolate (nº 04) on the upper and lower lash lines to frame your gaze, and a few coats of the Fabulous Eyes Smudgeproof mascara to make your eyes pop.

FACE: 
Finish off the look with our signature lit-from-within glow, by applying a touch of the universal Fabulous Skin Highlighter (nº01) on the high points of the face. 

🛍 Shop the look and discover the collection online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

#HERRERAINRIO

The Carolina Herrera Resort 2024 was held on Junes 1st in the heart of Rio de Janeiro, inspired by the city’s exuberant joy and sensuality.

At the heart of this celebration is the people of Brazil, boasting a 100% Brazilian cast, walking to a soundtrack of national icon Gal Costa.

Mother Nature and the tropical Brazilian climate proved to be the ultimate muse. As guests arrived to enjoy sunset cocktails and a breathtaking rainbow spanning the expanse of the stage, a rainstorm arrived upon the show location for a prolonged and unexpected period of time. Ultimately, guests were escorted to the adjoining party in a jungle greenhouse built for the occasion, as models were filmed in the rain barefoot holding their shoes, evoking an emotional and romantic image of the Girl from Ipanema.

GOLDEN NOIR by #HerreraBeauty

Transform your look with the perfect balance of gold shimmer, bold liner, and a velvety nude lip:

Step 1. Apply Chic Mono Eyeshadow in Shimmer Gold 17 all over your eyelids for a creamy, buildable gold shimmer that melts into the skin.
Step 2. Create a flawless wing with Fabulous Eyeliner, its waterproof, flexible formula allowing for easy, mistake-free lines.
Step 3. Add lashings of Fabulous Eye Smudgeproof Mascara for incredible volume, curl, and lift that lasts all day.
Step 4. Finish with Fabulous Kiss Blur Matte Lipstick in Nude Smile 140, leaving lips plump and velvety soft for up to 12 hours.

Radiant, powerful, and impossible to ignore.

Shop the look online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

The QUARTZ GLOW look is all about the perfect balance between bold eyes and a strong lip. 

Chic Mono Eyeshadow in Metallic Quartz 07 creates a luminous, translucent base, while Fabulous Eyeliner adds striking definition. Fabulous Eyes Waterproof Mascara builds dramatic volume and length, complementing the intensity of Fabulous Kiss Matte Lipstick in our signature red, Carolina 310. 

The result? A soft, bitten red lip that perfectly contrasts the boldness of the eyes, creating a look that’s essentially #HerreraBeauty.

QUARTZ GLOW by #HerreraBeauty

Elevate your look with the perfect mix of shimmer, precision, and a signature red lip:

Step 1. Sweep Chic Mono Eyeshadow in Metallic Quartz 07 over your lids for a translucent, wet-look glow that works beautifully on every skin tone.
Step 2. Create striking designs with Fabulous Eyeliner, its smooth-glide formula and precision tip making bold lines effortless.
Step 3. Add drama with Fabulous Eye Mascara in Waterproof, giving you extra-black, defined lashes with extra length for up to 24 hours.
Step 4. Complete the look with a freshly bitten effect using Fabulous Kiss Matte Lipstick in Carolina 310—a soft matte red that stays vibrant and never compromises on comfort.

Refined, radiant, and unmistakably Herrera.

Shop the look online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

#HerreraInCDMX

The Carolina Herrera runway show in CDMX took place at the iconic Museo Anahuacalli (@anahuacalli) in Coyoacán, a project conceptualized by Diego Rivera in collaboration with his daughter Ruth Rivera and architect Juan O’Gorman. The museum houses Mexico’s largest private pre-Hispanic collection and is designed as a pyramid, set within a fourhectare native garden, with an extension building conceived by architect Mauricio Rocha in 2021.

Museo Anahuacalli Director Teresa Moya and Curator Karla Niño de Rivera (@karlaninno) shared insights into this extraordinary project.

Film by @aranmartinezsolana.

-

El desfile de Carolina Herrera en CDMX tuvo lugar en el icónico Museo Anahuacalli (@anahuacalli) en Coyoacán, un proyecto conceptualizado por Diego Rivera en colaboración con Juan O’Gorman y su hija Ruth Rivera. El museo alberga la colección privada prehispánica más grande de México y está diseñado como una pirámide, ubicada dentro de un jardín nativo de cuatro hectáreas, con un edificio anexo concebido por el arquitecto Mauricio Rocha en 2021. 

La directora del Museo Anahuacalli, Teresa Moya, y la curadora del mismo, Karla Niño de Rivera (@karlaninno), comparten detalles sobre este extraordinario proyecto.

#HerreraInCDMX

En San Isidro Buen Suceso (Tlaxcala), en las faldas de La Malinche, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce @vicky.arce.946179 crea bordados inspirados en la belleza natural de su entorno. Su padre le enseñó a bordar cuando tenía 15 años y desde entonces se esfuerza por mantener viva una artesanía que también forma parte de la identidad de su comunidad. Con la ayuda de una vieja máquina de coser, ha elevado su oficio gracias a su exigencia y sensibilidad. En la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, las franjas bordadas de Virginia Verónica Arce Arce protagonizan tres vestidos que reflejan también el amor por la belleza y la naturaleza de esta comunidad de Tlaxcala. 

–

In San Isidro Buen Suceso, Tlaxcala, at the foothills of La Malinche, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce ( @vicky.arce.946179 ) creates embroidery inspired by the natural beauty around her. Her father taught her to embroider at age 15, and she has since dedicated herself to preserving a craft that is integral to her community’s identity. With the help of an old sewing machine, she has elevated her work through skill and sensitivity. For Carolina Herrera’s Resort 25 collection, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce’s embroidered panels take center stage on three dresses that reflect the love for beauty and nature shared by her Tlaxcala community.

En el corazón de México late la artesanía. Con motivo del desfile Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, que se presentó en el Museo Anahuacalli el 14 de noviembre, el director creativo @wesgordon colaboró con cuatro artesanas que conservan y proyectan al futuro la sabiduría de sus comunidades.
En San Isidro Buen Suceso (Tlaxcala), Virginia Verónica Arce Arce @vicky.arce.946179 ha refinado los bordados tradicionales con motivos que rinden homenaje a la cultura nahua. Las joyas que Araceli Nibra Matadamas @aracelinibra pinta y decora a mano a partir de jícaras son fruto de la cultura artesanal de Oaxaca. 

–

At the heart of Mexico lies its vibrant artisanal tradition. For the Resort 25 collection, presented at the Museo Anahuacalli on November 14, creative director Wes Gordon ( @wesgordon ) collaborated with four women artisans who honor and reimagine the wisdom of their communities.
In San Isidro Buen Suceso, Tlaxcala, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce ( @vicky.arce.946179 ) refines traditional embroidery with motifs celebrating Nahua culture. Meanwhile, in Oaxaca, Araceli Nibra Matadamas ( @aracelinibra ) paints and decorates jícaras by hand, transforming them into jewelry pieces that reflect the rich artisanal heritage of the region.

En San Pablo del Monte, Tlaxcala, se trabaja la talavera, una delicada cerámica esmaltada en blanco lechoso y azul. A Jacqueline España Capilla @jacqueline.espana.joyeria le fascinaba desde la infancia. Cuando acabó sus estudios de ingeniería química, decidió experimentar con ella y explorar sus límites. “Aquí, la talavera es una especie de reliquia que tienes guardada, que se utiliza como adorno o se saca en las ocasiones especiales, y yo quería llevarla conmigo todo el tiempo, usarla día a día”, explica esta artesana implicada con el desarrollo de su comunidad. En su colaboración para la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, sus joyas adornan vestidos y complementos. “Como artesana productora de talavera tengo el compromiso de cuidar el patrimonio que me fue legado, y velar por su salvaguarda, cuidando su esencia e impulsando la innovación”.

–

Talavera, a delicate white and blue glazed ceramic, has long been cherished in San Pablo del Monte, Tlaxcala. Jacqueline España Capilla ( @jacqueline.espana.joyeria ) was fascinated by it as a child. After completing her chemical engineering studies, she began experimenting with talavera, pushing its boundaries. “Here, talavera is like a relic, kept for decoration or special occasions, but I wanted to take it with me every day, to use it regularly,” explains this artisan, deeply committed to her community’s development. For Carolina Herrera’s Resort 25 collection, her jewelry adorns dresses and accessories. “As a talavera artisan, I’m committed to safeguarding the heritage entrusted to me, preserving its essence while driving innovation.”

#HerreraInCDMX

#HerreraInCDMX

Araceli Nibra Matadamas @aracelinibra vive y trabaja en Oaxaca, uno de los epicentros de la artesanía en México. Por eso colabora con toda una red de artesanos de confianza para reivindicar ciertos oficios desde una óptica contemporánea. Trabaja con latoneros, bordadoras o pintores, y ella misma decora jícaras con pintura, bordado, macramé y otros materiales. En el desfile de la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, Araceli Nibra colabora con una serie de piezas de joyería que reinterpretan sus célebres jícaras y emplean distintos materiales naturales.

–

Araceli Nibra Matadamas ( @aracelinibra ) lives and works in Oaxaca, one of Mexico’s craft epicenters. She collaborates with a trusted network of artisans to celebrate traditional crafts through a contemporary lens. Working with metalsmiths, embroiderers, painters, and more, she also hand-decorates jícaras using paint, embroidery, macramé, and other materials. For Carolina Herrera’s Resort 25 collection, Araceli Nibra contributed a series of jewelry pieces inspired by her signature jícaras, using various natural materials.

#HerreraInCDMX

En el corazón de México late la artesanía. Con motivo del desfile Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, que se presentó en el Museo Anahuacalli el 14 de noviembre, el director creativo @wesgordon colaboró con cuatro artesanas que conservan y proyectan al futuro la sabiduría de sus comunidades.
Los bordados de Maestra María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan @mariadelosangeleslicona (El Nanthe, Tenango de Doria, Hildalgo) son una oda a la belleza natural de la región y se plasman en diez prendas con contrastes de color. En Tlaxcala, Jacqueline España Capilla @jacqueline.espana.joyeria ha sabido reinterpretar la talavera tradicional, una cerámica esmaltada en blanco y azul cuyo origen se remonta a las culturas prehispánicas, para crear joyas y detalles ornamentales para varios modelos de la colección.

–

At the heart of Mexico lies its vibrant artisanal tradition. For the Resort 25 collection, presented at the Museo Anahuacalli on November 14, creative director Wes Gordon ( @wesgordon ) collaborated with four women artisans who honor and reimagine the wisdom of their communities.
María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan’s ( @mariadelosangeleslicona ) embroidery, from El Nanthe in Tenango de Doria, Hidalgo, is a tribute to the natural beauty of the region, featured on ten garments with bold color contrasts. Meanwhile, Jacqueline España Capilla (@jacqueline.espana.joyeria) from Tlaxcala reinterprets traditional talavera—a white and blue glazed ceramic with roots in pre-Hispanic cultures—into jewelry and ornamental details for several pieces in the collection.

#HerreraInCDMX

Maestra María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan @mariadelosangeleslicona aprendió a bordar de niña. En aquella época no había escuelas para las comunidades indígenas de El Nanthe, en Tenango de Doria (Hidalgo). “Pero con el apoyo de la costura he sacado adelante a mis ocho hijos”, explica. “La manta es mi cuaderno y la aguja es mi lapicero”. Para la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera, María de los Ángeles Licona ha creado los bordados de diez prendas. 

–

María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan ( @mariadelosangeleslicona ) learned embroidery as a child. At the time, there were no schools for the Indigenous communities of El Nanthe in Tenango de Doria, Hidalgo. “But thanks to sewing, I’ve been able to support my eight children,” she explains. “The fabric is my notebook, and the needle is my pen.” For Carolina Herrera’s Resort 25 collection, María de los Ángeles Licona created the embroidery for ten garments.

#HerreraInCDMX

On his inspiration trip to CDMX, Creative Director @wesgordon connected with the city’s creatives, exploring culture, architecture, art, and gastronomy. All insiders agree: Mexico City is the hottest city in the world right now.

Join us on Thursday November 14th at 6PM (CST) to discover the Carolina Herrera Resort 2025 Runway Show by Creative Director @wesgordon , streaming live from Mexico City.

Our first-ever see-now-buy-now collection will be available at carolinaherrera.com and select stores.

En su viaje de inspiración a la CDMX, el Director Creativo @wesgordon conversó con creativos de la ciudad sobre cultura, arquitectura, arte y gastronomía. Todos coinciden: Ciudad de México es, ahora mismo, la ciudad más vibrante del mundo.

Te esperamos el 14 de noviembre a las 6PM (CST) para descubrir la colección Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera diseñada por el director creativo @wesgordon , en directo desde Ciudad de México.

Nuestra primera colección see-now-buy-now estará disponible para compra y pre-order en carolinaherrera.com y tiendas seleccionadas.

#HerreraInCDMX

Come behind the scenes of our Resort 25 collection, as the brand’s decades-long bond with Mexico comes to life in a collection celebrating craftsmanship, culture, and inspiration. Drawing from the luminous sunsets of Mexico City, Wes Gordon collaborated with four artisans to create one-of-a-kind pieces that honor the best of Mexican artistry. Featuring works by Maestra María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce, Jacqueline España Capilla and Araceli Nibra Matadamas; this collection pays tribute to the cultures that continue to shape the brand.

Join us on Thursday November 14th at 6PM (CST) to discover the Carolina Herrera Resort 2025 Runway Show by Creative Director @wesgordon , streaming live from Mexico City.

Our first-ever see-now-buy-now collection will be available at carolinaherrera.com and select stores.

_

Descubre el proceso de creación de nuestra colección Resort 25, que celebra los lazos que desde hace décadas nos unen a México a través de la artesanía, la cultura y la inspiración. Fascinado por las luminosas puestas de sol de Ciudad de México, @wesgordon ha colaborado con cuatro artesanas para crear piezas únicas que representan la excelencia del talento mexicano. Con creaciones de la Maestra María de los Ángeles Licona San Juan, Virginia Verónica Arce Arce, Jacqueline España Capilla y Araceli Nibra Matadamas, esta colección rinde homenaje a las culturas que han dejado su huella en la marca.
 
Te esperamos el jueves 14 de noviembre a las 6PM (CST) para descubrir el desfile Resort 25 de Carolina Herrera diseñado por el director creativo @wesgordon, en directo desde Ciudad de México.
 
Nuestra primera colección see-now-buy-now estará disponible en carolinaherrera.com y en tiendas seleccionadas.

Furthering our commitment to celebrating women in the arts, @carolinaherrera partnered with @britishvogue for an intimate dinner at the Institute of Contemporary Arts in London. Co-hosted by Creative Director @wesgordon, Beauty Creative Director Carolina A. Herrera, together with British Vogue’s Head of Editorial Content @chiomannadi, and Global Beauty & Wellness Director @jessicadiner, the evening featured the digital works of artist @stefaniatejada, bringing together inspiring women from art, fashion, and beauty as we kicked off Frieze Week.

Photography by @sofi.adams.photo

Made for those who thrive on the thrill of possibility, Luckycharm embodies the essence of luck. Opening with the rich, deep aroma of freshly picked plum, its floral iris heart nods to classic elegance, while its base is a comfortingly creamy, warm vanilla that lingers on the skin. Spritz it when you’re feeling lucky, and remember — fortune favors the bold! 

Discover the rest of the #HerreraLuckycharms collection and shop online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

Why stay in when you could go out? At its heart, Call Me Darling is all abloom with orange blossom, a flower that radiates the warmth of sunlit days and the exciting promise of romantic evenings. Coming in an unexpected brown and pink, the bottle is an ode to the adrenaline of breaking the style rules, whilst its lipstick charm brings a flirty, feminine touch. 

Shop online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

#HerreraLuckycharms

Like your most flirtatious friend, Call Me Darling lives for fun. Playful yet elegant, its vibrant orange blossom heart is complemented by sweet, rich notes of cherry and the velvety embrace of a warm tonka bean base. As memorable as a first kiss, this rule-breaking, feminine scent is best worn with a cocktail in hand and a cheeky wink! 

Discover the entire #HerreraLuckycharms collection online and for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com.

A joyful family of couture fragrances, the #HerreraLuckycharms collection is feminine, bold and full of emotion, with each scent representing a different iconic flower. Nodding to the bold color combinations often used in Carolina Herrera’s runway collections, each scent is embellished with a charm that symbolizes the mood of the fragrance. Because a  fragrance is like a talisman! 

Discover all 6 scents and shop online for selected countries at carolinaherrera.com

#CarolinaHerreraSpring25
Postcards in motion from behind the scenes of the Carolina Herrera Spring 25 runway show, held on September 9 at 28 Liberty street, around Sunken Garden by Isamu Noguchi.

OPTIMISM AT PLAY: The Carolina Herrera Spring 25 collection begins in a study of black and white, with a considered focus on one exclamation point accentuating each look.

The collection blooms into color, in a tightly edited palette of four bold hues. Creative Director, Wes Gordon seeks perfection in each piece through the most precise choice of color, cut and silhouette, with an exacting dedication to graphic glamour. Adorned with yellow roses in their hair, models circle Isamu Noguchi’s circular Sunken Garden installation (1964), an ode to perfection in simplicity resonant in this collection, the polka dots in playful dialogue with the concentric circles of the sculpture.

#CarolinaHerreraSpring25

Adorned with yellow roses in their hair, models circle Isamu Noguchi’s circular Sunken Garden installation (1964). 

Discover the Spring 25 collection by @wesgordon now on www.carolinaherrera.com

Adorned with yellow roses in their hair, models circle Isamu Noguchi’s circular Sunken Garden installation (1964), an ode to perfection in simplicity resonant in this collection, the polka dots in playful dialogue with the concentric circles of the sculpture.

Yesterday evening, our founder Carolina Herrera was honored with the 2024 Hispanic Heritage Award for Fashion at the 37th Annual Hispanic Heritage Awards (HHAs) at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts’ Opera House in Washington, D.C. The award was presented to her by her dear friend, Musican and Producer Emilio Estefan.

The HHAs, supported by 40 national Hispanic-serving institutions, were established by The White House in 1988 to commemorate the creation of Hispanic Heritage Month in America, which is why they are often known as “America’s Hispanic Heritage Month Celebration.”

“The Hispanic Heritage Foundation is thrilled to honor the transcendent Carolina Herrera, a true global icon who has represented our community with such tremendous vision, determination and grace throughout her historic career,” said Antonio Tijerino, HHF President and CEO.

“It is an honor to receive the prestigious Hispanic Heritage Award which recognizes the tremendous contributions and legacy of Latinos in the United States and the world,” says Carolina. “I am proud to have the chance to celebrate our rich heritage and achievements with my fellow honorees. Thank you to the Hispanic Heritage Foundation for this great honor.”

Congratulations to the iconic Carolina Herrera on receiving the Hispanic Heritage Award for Fashion. To mark this prestigious occasion, we are honored to partner with Mrs. Herrera and create this one-of-a-kind doll dressed in custom @CarolinaHerrera couture, designed by Creative Director @WesGordon. 
 
Available for auction now through September 10, this @CarolinaHerrera x @BarbieStyle project will benefit @SolvingKidsCancer. Link in bio to bid and learn more.❤️ #CarolinaHerrera #HispanicHeritageMonth #Barbie #BarbieStyle 

Felicidades a la icónica Carolina Herrera por recibir el Hispanic Heritage Award for Fashion 2024. Para celebrar esta ocasión tan señalada, tenemos el honor de colaborar con Carolina Herrera y crear esta muñeca única vestida a medida por @CarolinaHerrera, con un diseño del director creativo @WesGordon. 
 
Disponible ya a través de una subasta hasta el 10 de septiembre, los beneficios de este proyecto @CarolinaHerrera x @BarbieStyle irán destinados a @SolvingKidsCancer. Link en bio para pujar y obtener más información.❤️ #CarolinaHerrera #HispanicHeritageMonth #Barbie #BarbieStyle

Congratulations to our Founder Carolina Herrera, who will be honored with the Hispanic Heritage Award for Fashion at the 37th Annual Hispanic Heritage Awards at the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts’ Opera House in September 2024. The HHAs, supported by 40 national Hispanic-serving institutions, were established by The White House in 1988 to commemorate the creation of Hispanic Heritage Month in America, which is why they are often known as “America’s Hispanic Heritage Month Celebration.”
 
“The Hispanic Heritage Foundation is thrilled to honor the transcendent Carolina Herrera, a true global icon who has represented our community with such tremendous vision, determination and grace throughout her historic career,” said Antonio Tijerino, HHF President and CEO. “We look forward to paying tribute to Carolina and all the Honorees through their accomplishments, cultural pride and our great promise to this country and the world.”
 
La Fundación Herencia Hispana anunció hoy que la diseñadora de moda venezolana-estadounidense Carolina Herrera, será honrada con el Premio a la Herencia Hispana 2024 en la categoría Moda, durante la XXXVII entrega anual, en el Opera House del Centro para las Artes Escénicas John F. Kennedy el septiembre de 2024. Los HHAs, respaldados por 40 instituciones al servicio de la comunidad hispana a nivel nacional, fueron establecidos por la Casa Blanca en 1988 para conmemorar la creación del Mes de la Herencia Hispana en Estados Unidos.
 
“La Fundación Herencia Hispana se enorgullece de honrar la trascendencia de Carolina Herrera, verdadero ícono global que ha representado a nuestra comunidad con visión, determinación y gracia, a lo largo de su carrera histórica”, resaltó Antonio Tijerino, presidente y director ejecutivo de HHF. "Nos emociona rendir homenaje a Carolina y al grupo completo de galardonados, por sus logros, aporte cultural, y la gran promesa que representan para este país y al mundo". Portrait by Gorka Postigo for Carolina Herrera

Global superstar @Shakira is Creative Director @WesGordon’s latest muse for this year’s Met Gala, celebrating the exhibition opening of “Sleeping Beauties: Reawakening Fashion.” Shakira wears a strapless crepe column gown in signature Herrera Red with a sculptural rose-shaped cape of 30 meters in silk gazar. To accessorize the look, Shakira carries a Herrera Red silk satin draped clutch.
 
A celebration of Carolina Herrera’s dedication to exemplary craftsmanship, Shakira’s striking look is a collaboration between Wes and the three lead female patternmakers of the atelier. The simplicity of the structured silhouette matched with the grandeur of the cape is a testament to the skill and expertise of the decade-spanning atelier – our very own Garden of Time.
 
Styling by Nicolas Bru @nicolasbrustyle
Hair by Jhonatan Rendon @_jhonatan_rendon 

#metgala

@Shakira's #MetGala look yesterday evening was in full bloom on the red carpet and in the atelier. Catalan artist @rosa_tharrats has transformed leftover Carolina Herrera textiles into ingenious sculptural pieces as part of a new exhibition in Barcelona. Her work stitches together textiles, upholstery, and clothing to create intricate installations that explore our relationship with organic and inorganic materials.

Refugia is open to the public at @bombonprojects in Barcelona until May 4.

Photography by @albayruela

For her new show at @bombonprojects in Barcelona, @rosa_tharrats used leftover Carolina Herrera textiles in her amazing sculptural pieces, including a show stopping blue and green tapestry covering the walls of the gallery that was built entirely with recycled fabrics.

“With the Carolina Herrera fabrics I used, I love the way they hang, the way they drape, and their colors,” she says.

Refugia is open to the public at @bombonprojects in Barcelona until May 4.

Photography by @albayruela

In our ongoing mission to celebrate women in the arts, Carolina Herrera has joined forces with Catalan artist @rosa_tharrats for a new gallery show in Barcelona. 

Tharrats is a visual artist who utilizes fabric for incredibly intricate sculptural pieces, exploring the relationship between organic and inorganic materials. 

For her Refugia exhibition — open to the public at @bombonprojects in Barcelona until May 4 — Carolina Herrera has donated leftover textiles from CHNY collections for her to use, including a show stopping blue and green tapestry covering the walls of the gallery. 

“My goal is to create sensorial atmospheres with layers of meaning,” she says.

Video by @albayruela

Delve into the Amazonian Rose universe

1. Carolina Herrera at Hacienda La Vega, photographed by Horst P. Horst, 1968.

2. Amazonian Rose fragrance bottle.

3. Top note, the freshness of Guatemalan cardamom.

4. Heart note, the accord of the iconic ‘Rosa de Venezuela’.

5. Base note, an accord of mystical Mexican copal.

6. Sketches of Hacienda La Vega details and gardens.

7. Carolina and Reinaldo Herrera photographed at La Vega, Caracas, 1979.

Introducing Amazonian Rose, the newest edition to Herrera Confidential. Inspired by a scentless flower, Amazonian Rose harks back to the early days of Mrs. Herrera's creative and artistic life, especially to Hacienda La Vega, her home in the heart of Caracas where a unique plant called 'La Rosa de Venezuela' thrived in the lush gardens.

"It's a flower that I grew up seeing. Yet, this flower has no scent," says Beauty Creative Director Carolina A. Herrera. "So, we decided to give it one."

To evoke the memories and sensations, Amazonian Rose combines cardamom from Guatemala, Damask rose, incense, and myrrh, all encased in a strikingly Herrera red glass bottle.

#HerreraConfidential

New York legend @maripolarama turned her famous Polaroid camera right to our front row at the FW24 show, including @avantika, @mariapedraza_, @nikkirodriguez, and @stxph.h.

The most beautiful women I know are powerful, strong and resilient. I designed the Carolina Herrera Fall 2024 collection to reflect this strength.

Silhouettes are streamlined, precise and clean. Ruffles are undulating and architectural in their form. Embellishments are intricately woven, beaded and embroidered. I am obsessed with the pursuit of craft.

New experiments in color blocking and new ways of dividing colors on the body in strong and intriguing combinations represent the next evolution in my language of color.

I am continually reaching for the height of elegance, the height of craft, the height of embellishment and that perfect detail. - @wesgordon

Video by @martinkeenan

Legendary artist @maripolarama made a name for herself snapping Polaroid photos of icons of the New York art scene of the 1970s and ‘80s. Now, commissioned by Creative Director @wesgordon, she’s turned her lens to our FW24 collection.

Backstage at the FW24 show, we caught up with New York artist @maripolarama, who, just like Carolina Herrera, first made a name for herself in the gritty, glamorous New York of the 1970s and '80s. It all came together at Studio 54, the Manhattan nightclub that everyone who was anyone — from Mick Jagger to Paloma Picasso, from Truman Capote to Mrs. Herrera herself — visited. 

Maripol is known for capturing portraits of the icons of that infamous era — like Andy Warhol, Grace Jones, Bianca Jagger, and Mrs. Herrera herself — with her famous Polaroid camera. Now, our Creative Director @wesgordon has asked her to turn her lens on Carolina Herrera’s FW24 show.

The Carolina Herrera Resort 2024 was held the 1st of June in the heart of Rio de Janeiro, inspired by the city’s exuberant joy and sensuality.

At the heart of the celebration was the people of Brazil, boasting a 100% Brazilian cast, walking to a soundtrack of national icon Gal Costa.

Mother Nature and the tropical Brazilian climate proved to be the ultimate muse. As guests arrived to enjoy sunset cocktails and a breathtaking rainbow spanning the expanse of the stage, a rainstorm arrived upon the show location for a prolonged and unexpected period of time. Ultimately, guests were escorted to the adjoining party in a jungle greenhouse built for the occasion, as models were filmed in the rain barefoot holding their shoes, evoking an emotional and romantic image of the Girl from Ipanema.

Vídeo narrated by @wesgordon Shop the collection now on Carolinaherrera.com

#HERRERAINRIO

Black diamonds, those astoundingly rare and precious gems, can take over a billion years to form under the surface of the earth — now, as part of our exclusive Herrera Confidential Collection, we’ve captured their essence in a new fragrance, Iris Empire, with orris, davana, patchouli and leather, and the extraordinary scent of iris. 

#HerreraConfidential

A black diamond is exceedingly uncommon, but, for our premiere Herrera Confidential Collection we’ve captured its essence in a new fragrance, Iris Empire, as seen on Emirati equestrian @marwaalhash. Now, you can spritz the spirit of rarity and brilliance right on your wrist. 

#HerreraConfidential

Today we celebrate Carolina Herrera's birthday, and none other than her daughter Carolina A. Herrera, our Creative Director of Beauty, wanted to wish her a very special day: "Happy birthday Mami! You are the best. I love you very much!"

Hot tip — did you know you can apply #HerreraBeauty’s Chic Mono Eyeshadows wet or dry? Re-create @chey_maya 's red carpet look with the shade Matte Linen 01 all over the eyelid as a base. As part of its mission to celebrate women through the arts, Carolina Herrera is proud to announce the sponsorship of the ‘Maestras’ (‘Women Masters’) Exhibition at the iconic Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum in Madrid, opening October 31 through February 4. The exhibit, curated by Rocío de la Villa, features paintings and sculptures by 73 groundbreaking female artists from the 16th to 20th centuries whose talent prevailed despite prejudice, discrimination and inequitable treatment, in an unexpected exploration on womenhood through symbolism, sisterhood, work, motherhood and beyond, as protagonists of their own fates.

Thanks to @museothyssen
Video by @albayruela

[Exhibition in collaboration with CAM.]

As part of its mission to celebrate women through the arts, Carolina Herrera is proud to announce the sponsorship of the ‘Maestras’ (‘Women Masters’) Exhibition at the iconic Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum in Madrid, opening October 31 through February 4. The exhibit, curated by Rocío de la Villa, features paintings and sculptures by 73 groundbreaking female artists from the 16th to 20th centuries whose talent prevailed despite prejudice, discrimination and inequitable treatment, in an unexpected exploration on womenhood through symbolism, sisterhood, work, motherhood and beyond, as protagonists of their own fates.

Artemisia Gentileschi, 'Judit and her Maidservant' (1618-1619)
Henriette Browne, 'A North-African Fellah' (1867)
Mary Cassatt, detail of 'Louise Nursing Her Child' (1898-1899)
Mary Cassatt, 'Breakfast in Bed' (1897)
Käthe Kollwitz, 'Mother with Two Children' (1980)

Thanks to @museothyssen
Pictures by @albayruela

[Exhibition in collaboration with CAM.]

As part of its mission to celebrate women through the arts, Carolina Herrera is proud to announce the sponsorship of the ‘Maestras’ (‘Women Masters’) Exhibition at the iconic Thyssen-Bornemisza National Museum in Madrid, opening October 31 through February 4. The exhibit, curated by Rocío de la Villa, features paintings and sculptures by 73 groundbreaking female artists from the 16th to 20th centuries whose talent prevailed despite prejudice, discrimination and inequitable treatment, in an unexpected exploration on womenhood through symbolism, sisterhood, work, motherhood and beyond, as protagonists of their own fates.

Marie-Louise Petiet, detail of ‘The Laundresses’ (1882)
Louise Catherine Breslau, detail of ‘Young Women’ (1893)
Anna Ruysch, detail of ‘Tulips and Roses in a Vase on a Marble Table’
Helene Schjerfbeck, detail of ‘Mother and Child’ (1886)
Victoria Polonia Malinowska, detail of ‘Fisherwomen from Ondarroa’ (around 1918)
Henriette Browne, detail of ‘A North-African Fellah’ (1867)
Berthe Morisot, detail of ‘The Sisters’ (1869)
Clara Peeters, detail of ‘Still Life with Flowers, a Silver-gilt Goblet, Dried Fruit, Sweetmeats, Bread sticks, Wine and a Pewter Pitcher’ (1611)
Lluïsa Vidal, detail of ‘The Housewifes’ (1905)
Paula Modersohn-Becker, detail of ‘Mother and Daughter, Half Figure’ (1906)

Thanks to @museothyssen
[Exhibition in collaboration with CAM.]

Yesterday evening, the @NYCBallet debuted a reimagining of Balanchine’s “WHO CARES?” as part of the Annual Fall Gala, with costumes designed by @WesGordon, inspired by the energy and vitality of New York City joined by Honorary Chair Carolina Herrera. 
 
The Balanchine favorite “Who Cares?” is set to a series of George Gershwin’s classic songs, and for the one-time-only gala evening, special guest vocalists Joshua Henry, Patti LuPone, and Vanessa Williams shared the stage with NYCB’s dancers to perform these iconic standards from the American Songbook. 
 
A beloved American classic which premiered in 1970 against the celebratory and glistening backdrop of New York City, this is the first time the NYCB has invited a fashion house to create an updated vision to the costumes on stage, in close collaboration with the George Balanchine Trust with respect to the original vision, color palette and attitude. “As a New Yorker, the NYCB and the Balanchine Trust is something I have the utmost reverence for as part of this city’s creative community,” says Wes. “Keeping in mind the elements that made the costumes inherently Balanchine, it was a pleasure to collaborate with NYCB on injecting elements of Herrera, such as soft romantic tulle and tonal embroidery, to bring these costumes to life on stage. It’s an honor to be part of this milestone event; this evening is as New York as can be.”

Image credit: Nina Westervelt

Picture it: Caracas in the 1970s, the soft scent of flowers in the air. Burning Rose, from our Herrera Confidential Collection, is inspired by the floral arrangements that Mrs. Herrera would create during her stays at Hacienda La Vega, her home in Venezuela. With a blend of Damask rose, black pepper, ginger, cinnamon, patchouli, and myrrh, it’s both comforting and exciting at once — the perfect bouquet.

#HerreraConfidential

With the strength of stallions and the warmth of home, Stallion Leather is inspired by Mrs. Herrera’s childhood infatuation with equestrian life. From our Herrera Confidential Collection, the scent combines ginger, jasmine (Mrs. Herrera’s favorite flower), citrus, and incense for an intense, nostalgic blend with plenty of horsepower.

#HerreraConfidential

Yesterday evening, the @NYCBallet debuted a reimagining of Balanchine’s “WHO CARES?” as part of the Annual Fall Gala, with costumes designed by @WesGordon, inspired by the energy and vitality of New York City joined by Honorary Chair Carolina Herrera. 
 
In attendance were guests in Carolina Herrera including gala chairs Sarah Jessica Parker and Naomi Watt, along with Ariana Debose and Dianna Agron with performances by Patti Lupone, Vanessa Williams and Joshua Henry.
 
The Balanchine favorite “Who Cares?” is set to a series of George Gershwin’s classic songs, and for the one-time-only gala evening, special guest vocalists Joshua Henry, Patti LuPone, and Vanessa Williams shared the stage with NYCB’s dancers to perform these iconic standards from the American Songbook. 
 
A beloved American classic which premiered in 1970 against the celebratory and glistening backdrop of New York City, this is the first time the NYCB has invited a fashion house to create an updated vision to the costumes on stage, in close collaboration with the George Balanchine Trust with respect to the original vision, color palette and attitude. “As a New Yorker, the NYCB and the Balanchine Trust is something I have the utmost reverence for as part of this city’s creative community,” says Wes. “Keeping in mind the elements that made the costumes inherently Balanchine, it was a pleasure to collaborate with NYCB on injecting elements of Herrera, such as soft romantic tulle and tonal embroidery, to bring these costumes to life on stage. It’s an honor to be part of this milestone event; this evening is as New York as can be.”

Images credit: Getty

Didn’t we tell you it would be love at first blush?

Queen Letizia of Spain joined King Felipe VI yesterday to inaugurate the Royal Collections Gallery at the Royal Palace in Madrid, wearing a floral Carolina Herrera New York dress designed by Creative Director Wes Gordon. 

La Reina Letizia de España inauguró ayer, junto al Rey Felipe VI, la Galería de las Colecciones Reales, en el Palacio Real de Madrid, con un vestido floral de Carolina Herrera New York diseñado por el Director Creativo Wes Gordon.

Creative Director @WesGordon has collaborated with photographer @ElizavetaPorodina on the book “COLORMANIA: Color and Fashion”, in partnership with publishing house @Rizzolibooks, set to be released on September 5th. 
 
With a foreword by British Vogue’s Editor in Chief and Vogue European Editorial Director @Edward_Enninful, COLORMANIA is a culmination of four years of creative partnership and a celebration of fashion, color, movement and beauty, featuring muses of different disciplines from dance (NYCB’s Wendy Whelan), modelling (Maggie Maurer, cover) to stage and music (Dove Cameron.) 
 
“The entire philosophy at Carolina Herrera is to embrace color, beauty, and alegría de vivir.  Elizaveta photographs in a very distinct painterly style, whereby she swaths color like a painter brushes color on a canvas.” says Wes. 
 
Get notified on when COLORMANIA arrives in stores by signing up on www.carolinaherrera.com #COLORMANIA
All eyes on you with Herrera Red and Carolina's initials. #CHInitialsInsignia #CHInsignia #CHCarolinaHerrera

Carolina Herrera is immensely proud to announce its new partnership with @spectaculu, a non-profit organization based in Rio de Janeiro that provides training and professional guidance to young people.

In September, the school will open a new Carolina Herrera course devoted to fashion and dressmaking, in furthering its mission of empowering communities through arts and creation. 15 young people will have access to a professional training course guiding them as they take their first steps into the fashion world. In addition, their initial class will be a virtual masterclass taught by none other than Wes Gordon — creative director of Carolina Herrera New York — himself.

Bem-vindos à Spectaculu!

#HERRERAINRIO
